**Flying in Weightlessness**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked normal from the outside. The pilot said it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights on the walls. Most of the seats were gone, except for a few at the back where the 13 students sat. They were nervous but excited. 

For 12 months, these students from Europe and America worked hard to join this flight. The European Space Agency asked them to think of fun experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, which felt like a big roller coaster. 

For the next two hours, the plane would go up and down like a bird. The pilot would turn off the engines at 3,000 meters. The plane would go higher for a moment before falling back down. During this time, everything inside the plane would be weightless. The students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.

The plane took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made the plane climb steeply. The engines roared, and the students felt heavy. Then, the engines stopped, and they felt weightless. For 20 seconds, they floated in the air. It was like jumping on a trampoline. They could not tell which way was up or down. 

After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up again. Gravity came back, and some students landed hard. They had 30 curves to do, which gave them 10 minutes of weightlessness for their experiments. 

The Dutch students studied their robot cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. They released a device to help with this. Another student accidentally landed on it during a curve. A German team studied how metal joins change without gravity, which is important for building space stations. 

A team from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films in microgravity. They believe these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a sailboat uses the wind. 

After two hours of flying, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I want to be an astronaut even more now."

**Text: 'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**

One day, I saw a helper bring a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset. We help orphaned animals. I heard strange noises from the box. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs. They were about eight inches long. They had soft fur and looked up at me with their milky eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before. 

Badger cubs are usually born between January and March. They live underground and if they lose their mother, they can die. These three cubs were found by builders. The builders accidentally hurt their home while working. The mother was dead, but the cubs were still alive. They were cold and scared. I took them to my kitchen to keep them warm. There were two girls named Primrose and Bluebell, and one boy named Willow. 

At first, I fed them with a syringe. I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to help them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around. They were happy with each other and a warm pad. 

Three weeks later, I saw that Willow was not very active, but he was still eating. I should have acted quickly. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. It was important to feed him slowly, but I did not know this. I felt sad about Willow, but I continued to care for the other cubs. 

Then, a farmer came to see me. He found another male cub, alone and hungry. I named him Willow II. He was younger than the girls. Feeding him was hard. I had to move the bottle around to help him drink. By the end of April, the girls were eating rice and other food. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle, but he made a mess when he ate. 

After a week, I gave him a sausage, and he learned to eat it. Soon, all the cubs were eating cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, and nuts. Badgers usually eat earthworms, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because it was a hot summer, and finding food was hard for others. 

By August, the badgers started to be active at night. We took walks in the orchard. The cubs would play and chase each other. I learned to avoid their playful bites. One night, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food. Badgers protect their homes, so we had to be careful. 

The local news took pictures of me with the badgers. Many people wanted to help build a home for them. We made plans for a sett with tunnels and a special gate. It took a lot of money, but local businesses helped us. 

One evening, the badgers moved into their new home. I watched them for a while and then left them alone. Later, I checked on them and saw three badgers sleeping. Now, I do not walk with them as much because they wake up late. Primrose has moved to another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before they run off into the night. This is their home now.

**Text: In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. He also did important work to understand how compasses work. 

Halley used his sea trips on a warship called Paramore to study the "variations of the compass." These variations are called "declination." Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to use their compasses correctly and navigate the oceans.

Halley planned to travel to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip ended early because of problems with the crew. But he tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a chart showing the variations of the compass in the oceans.

Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing his route. He needs to raise £70,000 for this journey. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.

Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life. Dr. Clark says, "Halley was a great scientist. He did many things, not just astronomy. He also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his work."

Dr. Clark's journey, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also be scientific. He will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. The Earth's magnetic field changes slowly, so these measurements are important. 

Dr. Clark explains, "We need to know true north to measure the direction of the magnetic field." He will use satellites to help with this. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip.

Halley's journey was the first scientific expedition at sea. He was the first civilian to be a naval captain for this kind of work. 

Dr. Clark has experience for this journey. He spent two years in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four parts with different crews. 

When asked if he is obsessed like Halley, Dr. Clark says, "I am ready to spend eight months on this journey. Some people might think I am obsessed, but I want to do this for a good reason. Halley and his life inspire me."

**Simplified Text:**

**PEACOCKS IN WHIPSNADE**

Every summer, peacocks walk around Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire. They show their beautiful tails to the hens. This is a mystery that Charles Darwin thought about a lot. He wondered how birds could have such big and colorful tails in nature, where it is hard to survive. 

Darwin said that living things change over time through evolution. He believed that the strongest animals survive and have babies. But he thought that peacocks' tails were not useful for survival. So, he created the idea of "sexual selection." This means that female birds like beautiful males just because they are beautiful.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if hens liked the males with the biggest tails, then those males must have something special that helps them survive. 

Now, 100 years later, scientists are still studying this. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Marion Petrie and her team want to answer two questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the biggest tails? And do these males have something extra that helps them survive?

The peacocks show off their tails in groups, and the hens choose the best ones. Observations show that hens like the males with the most eye spots on their tails. These males attract more mates. But it is still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University thinks that showy male birds are healthier and have fewer parasites. This means their beautiful feathers show they are healthy. However, Dr. Petrie and her team have not been able to check the health of the peacocks at Whipsnade yet.

This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the babies of attractive and unattractive males. She wants to see if the babies of attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would mean that the hens' choice is smart, just like Wallace said.

There is also an interesting idea from a mathematician named R A Fisher. He said that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will have long tails, and their daughters will like long tails. This could lead to more males with long tails over time. This idea supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty for beauty's sake. 

**Questions:**

1. Where do the peacocks live?
2. What do peacocks show to the hens?
3. Who thought about the mystery of peacocks' tails?
4. What is "sexual selection"?
5. What do the hens like in male peacocks?
6. What is Dr. Petrie studying this year?

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe says the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He made this idea real with his boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London has many beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. 

My boat is different. It is quiet and sits in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic for owning it. Maybe I am, but I don’t think so. My boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology helped a lot. 

However, new technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real sea life. Sailors often want to feel the sea when they go sailing. I don’t think sailors should go back to having a hard life. I like my boats to have a stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why should every sail work by itself? Sometimes, dealing with sails is part of being a sailor. 

A boat should be a boat, not a big house on the water. When I bought my first boat, Hirta, I sailed around Britain for a TV race. The last owner said she had comfort but no luxury. Hirta taught me that this was true. She had heavy sails, no running water, no electricity, no fridge, no heating, and no electronics, but she was the easiest boat I ever sailed. 

On land, classic boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but could not find one, so I decided to build a new boat. The Westerman has never let me down. 

The designer, Nigel Irens, used a computer to help design the boat, but he first drew it on a paper napkin. After making a model, we changed the design until it was perfect. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. It looks great, moves well in the sea, and feels peaceful inside. 

This is because it was made just for sailing, not for furniture. It shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it is good to learn from the past. Made from special wood, the boat does not take in water. It has the good parts of a fiberglass boat but looks and feels like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country hotels with spas are very popular now. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big old house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers were very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They have many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment made me feel like a new person. The staff were very friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to make some big changes this year, including a swimming pool. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a walk in the garden. I felt great when I left and I want to visit again. This is a perfect place for busy women. 

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. When I arrived, I saw a big staircase and a nice library. Everyone gets a health check when they arrive. They check your weight and blood pressure. I was called a patient, which felt strange because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem and helped me with it. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit. If you are not on a diet, you can eat tasty food in the dining hall. You can also have massages or water therapy. 

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys Manor is not a health farm, but it is a nice old hotel with cozy fires and a big lounge. If you want to lose weight, you might not enjoy the rich food. The chef makes delicious meals. The hotel has a gym and a pool to help you stay fit. There is also a spa and a clinic for sports injuries. I got advice for my shoulder pain. Careys is comfortable and relaxing, and there is beautiful countryside to explore.

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a beautiful country home and a five-star hotel. It treats guests very well. They offer health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, and horse riding. There are lovely walks and gardens. The restaurant has amazing food. I enjoyed my meal, especially the dessert. The next morning, I spent time in the gym to burn some calories. I also had a facial and a massage. Cliveden has everything you need for fitness and relaxation.

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is very tasty but has a lot of calories. The second best thing is the aromatherapy massage. I felt so relaxed during the massage that I fell asleep. The hotel is modern and has many beauty rooms. There are many treatments available, like manicures and facials. The guests are a mix of people, from families to friends. I would love to visit Springs Hydro every month.

**NATURAL TALENTS**

Humans and chimpanzees have been separate for about seven million years. We are still very similar to chimpanzees. We share more than 98% of our genes with them. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very new. 

Our ability to make art and do other things that are special to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. Studies show that many things we thought were only human are also found in animals. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and to fight. Sea otters use rocks to open clams. 

Monkeys also have a simple form of language. They make different sounds to warn each other about leopards, eagles, and snakes. This shows that there are not many big differences between humans and animals, except for art.

If art is special to humans, it is strange that our ancestors did not make art for almost seven million years. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we cannot find these old materials. The first clear evidence of human art is from about 35,000 years ago. This includes cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways: 

1. Human art is not made for a purpose. 
2. Human art is made for beauty and pleasure. 
3. Human art is learned, not instinctive.

Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive like animal behaviors do. Some human art does communicate ideas, but this is not the same as passing on genes. Bird songs help birds defend their territory and attract mates, which helps them pass on their genes. 

The second point is that we do not know if birds enjoy their songs. They sing mostly during the breeding season, so they may not sing just for fun. This makes human art seem special.

The third point is that human art styles are learned. Different groups of people have different art styles. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. But some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs. They can sing even if they have never heard the song before.

Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell when a painting was made just by looking at it. In 1957, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy had an art show in London. Congo made many paintings and was upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were sold, which is something many human artists cannot do.

These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were made for enjoyment, not for a specific purpose. Some people might say that human art is different because it is meant to communicate. However, some famous human art was made just for the artist's own pleasure.

**Text: A Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a very big and dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left in the world. In the past, stories for children were about brave explorers. These explorers had sunburnt skin and looked far into the distance. Today, we do not see such people in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Charles Blackmore led a group of people across the Taklamakan Desert. The desert is very hard to cross. Its name means "once you enter, you never come out," and local people call it the Desert of Death. Charles talked about the dangers and excitement of his journey at home with his family. 

His team had four British people (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for everyone. 

They set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He wanted to have fun and find out who he really was. His wife, Tina, was worried that he might not come back because no one had ever crossed that route before. 

It took them 59 days to cross the desert. Charles said the desert was very kind to them. The team faced many problems: they got sick, felt very hot and thirsty, and lost some of their water. But they found water when they needed it. They did not have to deal with big sandstorms or very cold weather. 

Charles said, "What pushed me to keep going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. We were alone in the desert." He was scared about whether he could finish the trip. On the first day, it was so hot that he could hardly breathe. He thought, "We have to do this now!" 

After walking 1,000 kilometers, they did not want to stop. They were very thin but strong. Charles felt fit and could walk over anything. 

In the middle of the book, Charles described lying in the desert and looking at the full moon while thinking of his family. He felt he needed to find peace with himself. He said, "I feel prouder of this trip than anything else I have done. But my family and our happiness are more important than the desert."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? He said, "I want the challenge and the open spaces. I find it hard to live in the same way as everyone else today."

**Simplified Text:**

Susan Harr is tired of technology. She decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. We think we need gadgets to save time. But Susan had a bad experience with her broken computer. It cost her a lot of money to fix it. She wonders if we really need all this technology.

Little by little, Susan stops using some of her gadgets. She thinks about what "time" technology gives us. Does it really give us more time for fun? She feels that companies trick us into buying more gadgets. When her computer made strange noises, she put it outside. Now, she is not tied to a noisy machine. She can take her time to sew by hand.

Susan knows some gadgets are useful, like her washing machine. But she also finds joy in not using some gadgets. She and her family watched too much TV, so they returned their color TV and now use a small black-and-white one. This helps them spend more time walking their dog, reading, and talking. Susan used to have a sewing machine, but now she sews by hand. 

She thinks people believe they cannot live without gadgets. But she enjoys sewing and listening to the radio or talking to friends. She can even watch TV while doing simple sewing. Sewing by hand is relaxing, and she feels happy doing it. 

Susan also enjoys washing dishes by hand. She thinks about what gadgets she really needs. Do they need a freezer, a microwave, or an electric lawnmower? She believes they could save money by not using so many electric things. 

**Questions:**

1. What does Susan decide to do with her gadgets?
2. Why did Susan have a bad experience with her computer?
3. What does Susan think about the time technology gives us?
4. What did Susan and her family do with their color TV?
5. What does Susan enjoy doing while she sews by hand?

Text: 'Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems to be a busy man. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he greets me quickly and says, "Well, let's start!" He is busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wood in many colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years. He has a good reputation. Many people want to order furniture from him, and he is very busy. 

It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is hard to find one who makes furniture with good quality. Hurst says, "There are not many real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is not happy with some modern furniture. He thinks some furniture-makers do not make good work. Hurst wants to make perfect furniture, and this is why he is successful. He is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a natural ability. I have always been good at making things." 

Hurst learned his craft by asking questions. Most of his work comes from private clients. Some clients come back to him many times. He enjoys making furniture for their whole house. But sometimes, clients do not know what they want, and this can be frustrating. He likes clients who know what they want. 

Hurst is proud of his work, but he also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people better than me." He does not like craftsmen who take a long time to make one piece of furniture. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just a fashion statement. Hurst is confident, but he is also humble. He says, "After all, I am only making furniture," as I leave.'

**Text: Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. Sleep is very important for us. But, scientists do not agree on why we need sleep. There are three main ideas.

The first idea says that sleep is good for our bodies. When we sleep, our bodies fix themselves and get better. 

The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us remember things we learned during the day. Without sleep, we cannot learn well.

The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to have energy for the next day. Sleep helps us feel ready and strong.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of their society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, some people like to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics.

Eccentricity shows our individuality. Inside us, there is a struggle between two feelings. One feeling is to be ourselves, and the other is to fit in with others. Most people want to be accepted and liked, so they often choose to fit in rather than stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and hold meetings to talk about what they like or their problems. They want to share their interests with others who understand them. Being in a group can make them feel better.

We all feel a mix of wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. Even when we follow the crowd, we may not like it when someone says we are doing that. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. 

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Many successful people do this. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and go for it, you will surprise many people." But being different is not the same as trying to be noticed. 

If a singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, that is not eccentricity. But if they keep being different for a long time, they may become eccentric. The key to eccentricity is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are.

True eccentrics do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

**Simplified Text: Natural Books**

We asked four nature experts to tell us about a book about wildlife that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward. She is a small, frail woman, but she is very important for environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these issues. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think Barbara's most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes in her life. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the guano in the sun. This book explains well, with words and pictures, how animals communicate. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaos turns into a smart social structure. You can see which birds are partners and where their boundaries are. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to explain his work to everyone. He worked with a talented wildlife artist, Eric Ennion, to make this book interesting for all wildlife lovers. Eric's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and how another is calm. This is the art of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced my life the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book helped me find a wonderful husband and a great career in conservation. It also made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. I had been there for two years and was feeling sad because of many problems. But when I opened "My Family and Other Animals," my world became brighter. The book shows animals, people, joy, and beauty together. Many people say humans are bad because of what we have done to other species. But I like to remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to it because of the 48 beautiful pictures of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. These books made me start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" had much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature more. It showed me that my feelings and creativity about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**Text: DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in the newspaper. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or word of mouth. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews. Publishers also feel sad, but they think that any review, good or bad, can help sell books. They like reviews that match their own feelings about a book.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both want good book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed well. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help people know about their books. Good reviews can help sell books, especially if there are many of them.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Many books are not by famous authors, so publishers need good reviews to sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show the reader that the review is honest. Good reviews can help a book sell well, but they need help from other things like recommendations from friends and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the connection between publishing and reviewing is not clear. In the United States, a review in the New York Times can make a book popular. In Britain, bookshops may not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews can still sell very well. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to talk more about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would buy it. Now, sometimes a surprising reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

**Text: WEATHERVANE MAKER**

Making weathervanes is an old skill. It started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes them by hand. Graham creates special designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a unique gift." Many of his customers are women who want to buy gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies.

Most weathervanes are shaped like cockerels, but Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. Graham saw that he could make many different designs. He decided to start a weathervane business. Before this, he worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed jobs. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and build his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting."

Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before he cuts it by hand. He also keeps traditional designs in stock because people like them too. Graham says, "People like handmade things. They want something different."

Graham does not want to grow his business. He wants to keep it a small craft. He enjoys making unique weathervanes. He says, "For many years, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction." Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want special items for their homes. This helps crafts like his.

Graham is busy and sends weathervanes to customers all over the world. People from America and Denmark are especially interested. He says, "The price depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Simplified Text:**

**A New Writer's Success**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans. He earned a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his ideas and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not doing well. A film he was working on did not happen. He was worried because he had not made money for two years. He needed money to pay the bank. A smart person would have found a job, but Nicholas did something different. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.

Nicholas had an idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became very angry. The owners were sad until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and change its behavior. These people are called "horse whisperers." Nicholas was very interested in this idea.

He started to learn more about horses and the people who work with them. He drove around the US, visiting ranches. He felt alone and worried about his life. He had tried to be a filmmaker for ten years, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.

By the end of August, he had written the first half of the book. The bank manager was getting angry, and he needed to know if he should keep going. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for it. Nicholas needed this money to pay off some of his debt.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say that they had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Nicholas was surprised. His agent felt something good was going to happen.

A week later, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a record for a first novel. Nicholas and his team could not believe it. They did not send the book to New York, but it got there anyway. Many movie studios wanted to make a film from it.

Nicholas was happy but also careful. He did not want to write the movie script because he liked the way things were going. He wanted to write another novel instead.

**Simplified Text:**

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is getting older. He wants to play chess again. Chess is now a game for young people. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is back and playing against Boris Spassky, his old rival. Bobby won the first game, and it was a great game. But Bobby is now 49 years old. He has not played much and is not in good shape. Boris Spassky is also older.

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Bobby Fischer made chess popular. Now, many players want to win more than anything else. In chess today, a player needs to be strong and calm, not just smart. The game is very intense. Players have a chess clock to keep time. If they do not make their moves in time, they lose the game. Games can be long, and players often do not take breaks. This makes it harder for older players.

In the last 30 years, new world champions have been younger. Most of the top ten players are under 30 years old. Chess is also played differently now. Players prepare a lot before matches. Computers help players study many chess games. They can find out how to beat their opponents. In some matches, players have teams to help them prepare.

A chess game can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock makes it even more stressful. At the end of the game, players often rush to make their moves. They have only a few seconds to finish. This is very exciting and tense.

Winning a game feels great, but players must be ready for the next game. Chess tournaments can last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even harder. One match in 1984 lasted for months and had to stop because the players were too tired.

Bobby Fischer loves chess. He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." He left chess after 1972, which was surprising. If he is back for money, he will earn a lot. But if he wants to prove he is the best, it could be very hard for him.

**Text: Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.

A. Nick Grosso is a man in his early 30s. He has written three plays that people like. He is now making his first play, Peaches, into a movie. "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low," he says. "It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but before he wrote Peaches, he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I did not think it would be performed," he says. "It is set in a car. I would not do that now because I know it is hard to do." He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted people to hear my writing," he says. "I was happy to be with people who liked the same things. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."

B. Simon Pegg is 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a comedy show for TV and just finished a long tour with comedian Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he was practicing comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "I realized I did not want to be a regular actor. I liked comedy more. People think comedy is very hard, but it is not. If you have courage and good material, it is great to make people laugh." He has worked with the comic group Funny Business, but his best work is with Steve Coogan. "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his," Simon says.

C. Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he danced in the show The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked him a lot. "It has been a great chance for me," he says. "Now, I can choose what I want to do." This is a good place to be, especially since he just finished school. Ciaran acted in school plays and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. "I used acting to avoid homework," he laughs. "But then I wanted to be serious about it because I liked it." Now, he waits for praise, but he thinks about fame. "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you learn it is not why you act. It is about respect for good work."

D. Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They just signed a deal for three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their song, Chimera, comes out. "The record company has different ideas about success than I do," he says. "They want a big hit, but I will be happy if two people buy it." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for many years. "It is funny how things happen," he says. "I was tired after doing many small gigs and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who helped me form Matrix. It was a good time for me."

E. Stephen Richards is 27 years old. He is a poet and writer who has won many awards. He is well known in the poetry world and has been giving readings for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. "It is a story about obsessive love. I could not write it as a poem," he says. Stephen loved creative writing in school but did not like school later. "I did not go to university, but I got bored working at a theater and decided to go," he explains. After university, he published his first book for children in 1992. "My parents did not think I would be a writer. They thought I would just read because I read a lot as a child." Now, he is brave to write novels. "Poetry has rules, but novels can be any length. I want to make sure my writing is good."

**Text: Volunteer Tourism**

Four writers talk about international volunteer work.

A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money went directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for gap years, where volunteers often do not need special skills or experience. Many studies ask if gap year volunteering is really about helping others or if young people want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help people learn to be kind and help those who have less.

B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can also help solve problems, allow more people to take part in global issues, and create international friendships. In this way, everyone can benefit, and it can help the world. But if only rich people can volunteer, it may help them in their careers but not help the communities that need it. Volunteers will keep getting benefits while using local organizations and communities to help themselves.

C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be like a rich person trying to help but really just helping themselves. It can also be a way to give real help to communities. When done well, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the organizations they work with. It can also help people understand and care about the problems of poverty and injustice.

D. Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others. This idea can seem good, especially when people do not trust big governments or businesses. It seems positive because it focuses on personal help. But it can also ignore the need for real change in poor communities. Some people think volunteering is not enough. While volunteer tourism can be simple and good, when it is sold as a way to help develop communities, it can show a misunderstanding of the real problems of poverty in the world.

**Text: Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?

I, Tom Granger (an inventor), and Paul Bridges (a broadcaster) tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times. One for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs this? This model costs about the same as another one we tested. It has a cassette player, so you can listen to your own tapes to fall asleep and wake up to music. We all thought the radio quality was very good, but the clock radio is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "I need space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm does not work."

This model was voted the best. Paul Bridges said he loved it, but the clock kept getting stuck at 4:00 PM. I liked the digital display with nice grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it easily. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I accidentally pressed them too much. The clock has a backup battery, so it still works if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But setting it up was hard. When we finally did it, we felt cool and smart.

Tom Granger said this model with a lamp was "very cheap" in quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The light was hard to move, and you could not read by it. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but said the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, and it made me want to throw it away. Still, this model is the third most popular one.

This clock radio is bright and colorful. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. He said, "I would choose this one because it is different." The controls were easy to use, and we set it up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 20 minutes early or late. Paul Bridges laughed at this and said the model was "very annoying" and "useless."

The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are not sure if you pressed them right. He agreed that radio quality has improved with new technology. I thought the tuning was not very good, but the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Text: Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a tight ball. The spines stick out to protect it. Some hedgehogs, like those in the desert, have fewer spines. They may try to run away instead of rolling up. 

Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all do. Some hedgehogs stay awake all year if the weather is good.

**Text: Great Sportswomen**

It is hard to be good at any sport, even for men, but women have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they must make sacrifices. But they are proving that they can succeed and break records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski and feel great when I jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel good or the weather is bad, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I don’t have much time for friends. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete together and are treated the same."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and I won! I was surprised because I had never cycled before. Now, I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools have rowing teams. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so it is difficult to have a strong team. But I enjoy it and like being fit, and I have fun with my teammates."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very hard. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and had many blisters. But I set a record! Some people think women are less likely to succeed, so it is harder to get sponsors."

E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing can be tough. Men often want to beat me, and I have had many accidents. It is hard to earn money, and I spend what I make on my sport. More women are racing now, which is great!"

F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need to sleep on other mornings. In the evening, I cycle or run. Sometimes I feel very tired! Racing is hard, but I am happier when I stay fit. Men and women usually compete together, but the news often talks more about the men’s events. The prize money for women is not as good, but we are working to change that."

**Text: Shopping Tricks**

Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that stores use to make you spend more money.

A. **Fresh Food**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The colors in the store, like green, can make you think of fresh food. But most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.

B. **Product Placement**  
Where products are in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where people look for items the most. They put the most expensive products at eye level because people are more likely to buy them. Special bins with discounts can also attract shoppers. Sometimes, stores put items that go well together near each other, like ice cream and toppings.

C. **Moving Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place cheap items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more expensive items on their way. Stores also put popular products far from the entrance, hoping that customers will look for them and see other items they might want to buy.

D. **Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show their clothes in a way that makes them look special. They do not put many items on display, which makes shoppers think the clothes are unique. This good design helps the store sell more clothes.

E. **Total Price**  
Shoppers often pay more attention to the total price of their shopping than to the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. Sometimes, they sell cheap items at a loss to bring people into the store. They can get lower prices from manufacturers by buying in large amounts.

F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, a blouse priced at £14.99 seems cheaper than one at £15. This pricing can also help reduce theft in the store.

G. **Lighting**  
Stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so shoppers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.

H. **Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the way through the store, and another shows sales areas. This helps shoppers move through the store, but some may not want to explore the sales areas.

I. **In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. In some stores in the U.S., shopping carts have screens that show ads for products while you shop. These ads are meant to catch the attention of shoppers and can increase sales a lot.

**A Simple History of the Apple**

Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the old types of apples.

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored apple halves for winter. These apples were small and wild, called crab apples. They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Apples (1000 AD)**  
The Romans taught the French how to grow fruit. This knowledge came to Britain. The Romans brought some apple types, but they did not grow well in Britain. The French apples became more popular. British monks also grew new types of apples. Most apples we have today come from these old varieties.

**Medieval Apples (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, many apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a common dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad weather and diseases made it hard to grow apples. Many apples were imported from other places. In the sixteenth century, King Henry VIII asked a fruit expert to learn about growing apples in France. He brought back many new apple types.

**Apples in New Lands (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia. The Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in North America.

**New Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. He named the apple 'Delicious' after a judge said it was very tasty. This apple became very popular. Another famous apple, Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She found a small tree growing from old fruit and took care of it. This tree grew green apples that became famous.

**Modern Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from a few types that are chosen for their looks and how well they travel, not for their taste. Many old apple types are disappearing. In the UK, some gardeners keep old varieties alive, but in the US, many apples are gone forever. People want more types of apples. We need to protect the different kinds of apples for everyone to enjoy.

**Text: Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a travel company that offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique places and interesting activities. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**  
We travel in small groups of about 16 people. This makes it easier to learn about the places we visit. You can meet local people and enjoy a more personal experience.

**Different Ways to Travel**  
We use many types of transport on our trips. Sometimes we travel by bus, train, boat, or even on foot. Each trip is special and shows the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**  
Our travelers are interesting people who like to try new things. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone who is healthy, fit, and open to new experiences. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. Some travel as couples, while others travel alone.

**Activities and Interests**  
Each trip is unique, so we have different categories for our adventures. These categories highlight special activities. Many trips focus on culture, like visiting historical sites in Egypt, India, or Greece. We also have wildlife safaris where you can see animals in their natural homes.

**Cultural Experiences**  
On our trips, you can meet different ethnic groups, like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to help promote understanding between cultures.

**Easy Hiking**  
Some trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can stay in hotels or local homes. We have trips in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand.

**Major Treks**  
For strong walkers, we offer challenging treks in high mountains. You may stay with local people or camp in the mountains. We provide support, so you don’t have to carry heavy bags.

Discover remote areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These trips are exciting and offer a chance to see beautiful landscapes.

We also have relaxing boat trips. You can sail in Egypt or travel between islands in Greece. Our river journeys can be short or long, and no experience is needed. You will learn safety skills quickly.

Explore Worldwide offers many adventures for everyone who loves to travel and discover new places!

**The Problems with Advertising**

Many people know that advertising is not doing well. This is not just because of the economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got bad. The problems with advertising are serious and happen all over the world.

Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from brands you see in ads. You might buy a few well-known brands, but you do not buy many different brands in a year. You probably buy about 400 different brands each year, but there are many more brands advertised.

When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that only about 1 in 16 ads are for brands they might buy. 

Many people think they are different and do not pay attention to ads, but this is not true. Most people do not buy most of the brands they see in ads. It is normal for advertising to waste money because not everyone will buy the products they see.

If an advertiser knows who will buy, they can talk to them directly. But this is not possible with ads. If an advertising campaign can get 2% of the population to buy a product, it is very successful.

Charles Clover visits a very green home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, England. This place has two interesting things. First, it has Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral with carvings of 'green' men made by craftsmen long ago. Second, it has the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale.

The house is designed to keep out drafts, even the cats have their own small door.

Robert and Brenda teach architecture at Nottingham University. They cared about the environment before it was popular. They wrote a book about green homes in the 1970s. They wanted to build a house that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They made special toilets and used rainwater tanks. They filter the water before using it. Robert says they want to show that it is possible to build a house that is good for the environment. The house looks modern, but the hall has a staircase that goes up to the top. Text: 'The Camera and Fairies

Arthur Conan Doyle wrote the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a smart man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw pictures of fairies in a garden. He believed these pictures were proof that fairies were real. He wrote an article and published the pictures, saying fairies are wonderful.

In 1939, the two women who took the pictures said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them in the flowers. The pictures are very pretty. But this shows that photography can be tricked. People often think that a camera always tells the truth. But it can lie. Today, we can change pictures with computers. Photography has never been completely true.'

**Text: Blacksmiths**

For a long time, iron has been very important to people. The men who work with iron, called blacksmiths, are not just skilled workers; they are also seen as artists. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and tools for farming.

In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. In France and Belgium, blacksmiths created lovely metal designs for buildings. However, by the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain because heavy industry did not need them anymore. Modern architects often did not use beautiful ironwork.

In the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again. People are more interested in decorative architecture and new interior design. However, much of the new work looks similar to old styles, like "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find many trendy stores selling rusty candlesticks.

There are events happening soon to promote blacksmithing. The first event is an exhibition of ironwork by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says this could be the start of a new Iron Age. He believes that both the public and blacksmiths are seeing new possibilities.

With power tools, blacksmiths can work more easily. They can bend and shape metal without much effort. Dawson says, "These artists can now express themselves with metal." About 250 pieces of work are in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the blacksmiths, but some will help promote good ironwork.

Dawson has made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "I let the steel bend and flow when it is hot. It is like drawing with metal." Many artists love working with iron. Susan May, a jeweller, says, "It is magical because it is soft when hot, but hard when it cools down." 

Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles that look like things from horror movies. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard. It feels like it will last forever." Iron gives people joy and a sense of security. It is likely that iron will be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we do not see any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING**

I thought my friends would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I could not explain how I went from smoking a lot to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was strange for me too.

I went to a stop-smoking class two months and three weeks ago. I did not plan to stop smoking, and I did not really want to. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. I was healthy and did not often get sick. I thought I was fine.

On that Thursday afternoon, I went to the class to write an article about it. I said, "I will not try to stop. I am here to write, not to stop." I liked smoking. It made me happy. The teacher looked at me like she understood. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. 

I began to think that stopping smoking was a good idea. I felt strong because I could stop. The need for cigarettes went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was not a problem. I was surprised that the hardest part was being at home on weekends. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. 

I do miss smoking a little, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is different. Eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, and waiting at the theater are all moments when I used to smoke.

**Simplified Text:**

Dorothy Hodgkin is a British woman scientist who won the Nobel Prize. Many people in Britain do not know her name. For four years, I have asked my friends if they know about her. If they do, they pass my test. 

Dorothy Hodgkin is important because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. She died in 1994. She studied crystals and had a very interesting life. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like better education for women and the growth of science around the world.

When I started my research, I wanted to read about other scientists. A friend told me to read about Linus Pauling, who was a friend of Hodgkin. He was also a famous scientist and won Nobel Prizes. I went to a bookshop, but I could not find any books about him. I was surprised that people did not find him interesting, even though he was very important.

Some scientists think that their lives are not interesting to read about. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often boring. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and bookshops feel the same.

Many people do not know about scientists' lives. Some scientists do not want to be in the media because they do not want to seem like they are showing off. This makes it hard for young people to see science as interesting.

However, things are changing. Scientists are now seen more in public. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people.

Books about scientists are also changing. They used to be very serious and boring. Now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show that scientists can have fun and interesting lives. Famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Marie Curie are now shown with their flaws.

Dorothy Hodgkin worked hard in science. She solved the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in 1964. She also worked on insulin in 1969. She had three children and a husband who was often away for work. Her personal life is important, and we can learn from how she balanced everything.

Hodgkin loved science. It is important for scientists to share their passion. However, many readers find scientific ideas hard to understand. Learning science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just takes practice.

**Text: Margaret and Her Water Finding**

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers need her help because their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines to drill wells, but Margaret uses the hazel stick to find water.

Margaret is very good at her job. She finds water more than 90% of the time. This ability to find water is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special skill. There are different ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water.

In recent years, many farmers have needed help because of droughts. Most of Margaret's customers are farmers. They usually only need her help once because wells last a long time. Some customers have holiday homes far from water pipes. Others are building golf courses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid waste in the water. The water she finds is clean, but she must be careful about minerals in the water. She also needs electricity to pump the water, so the well should be close to power sources.

To find water, Margaret first looks at a map. She uses a pendulum over the map. If the pendulum swings, there may be water below. Then, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels something special. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill.

Margaret holds the stick with both hands. If the stick rises, it means water is below. It is important to drill in the right place. If she and her husband do not agree on where to drill, they will keep looking until they do.

Margaret's ability to find water is interesting to many people. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding where water is. This skill helps her family run their well-drilling business successfully.

Have you ever wanted to live like someone else for a day? Four people did this. Here are their stories.

**A. Amanda's story**  
I am Amanda, 23 years old. I am a mother with two daughters. I swapped lives with my friend Cindy, who is 30 years old and works in a busy restaurant in London. 

I had never been in a place like this before. It was dark and loud, and there were many people. I felt nervous! Being a mother is busy, but this was different. I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. The other waitresses made it look easy, but I dropped the drinks on the floor! I felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

When the restaurant opened at 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers. I was worried about remembering their orders, but the computer helped me. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. I had to say "Pardon?" a lot when customers spoke to me, which was embarrassing. By 5 pm, I was very tired. I was surprised when a waitress said it was a "quiet" day! I never knew waitressing was so tiring. I thought it was an easy job, but you need to be friendly and calm. I am shy, and I don’t think I could work on a busy night. I was happy to go back to my children. Taking care of them seems easy after waitressing!

**B. Cindy's story**  
I am Cindy, 30 years old. I was nervous about being a mother for a day, but I was also excited. Amanda warned me that her daughters were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. 

When Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! Amanda reminded me to clean the house and do the laundry. 

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. When I brought Sophie home, they started jumping on the couch and screaming! I thought they would get tired, but they didn’t. I tried to get them to sleep by 8 pm, but then they wanted more water. I knew they just wanted to watch TV! It was tiring to spend all evening talking to them. I never knew taking care of two small children could be so hard. You don’t have time to think about yourself. But I really enjoyed the day!

**C. Rosemary's story**  
I am Rosemary, 42 years old. I run a dairy farm. I woke up at 5:30 am, but today I could sleep until 7 am! I was nervous about how to look at school. I didn’t want to stand out. 

At school, I saw about 400 students. I hoped I could blend in. I helped in a math class and a nature project. By lunchtime, I was tired but only had five minutes to eat! There was a lot to do before the next classes. I went to a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, I had a reading lesson and a French lesson. The children wanted to practice French with me, which was fun. Finally, we had Physical Education. I was very tired, but the children had a lot of energy. Speaking in front of the class was hard for me. Teachers have more holidays, but I think I will stay on the farm!

**D. Hilary's story**  
I am Hilary, 30 years old. I arrived at Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am, but she had been up for three hours! Rosemary has a big farm with cows and sheep. 

I spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice-cream. It was hard not to eat the ice-cream! At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. If a sheep falls over, it needs help quickly. After feeding the calves, I started milking the cows. It took two and a half hours! Rosemary does this twice a day, every day. 

I felt lonely. I missed the children because animals don’t talk back! The hardest part is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked every day. Farming seems nice, but it is very hard work. The money is not always good, and I wouldn’t like to depend on the weather.

I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work to arrive at 9:30 am. I check the mail and see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing furniture to customers and selling it. We sell old furniture that costs between £1,000 and £6,000. I also work with people who fix the furniture. I read a magazine about antiques while I drink coffee. I do the accounts once a month and go home at 5:30 pm.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work in shifts. If I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start work at 7:00 am and help control the planes. I work with a team and we manage many flights every day. At night, it is quieter, and I can read about new rules. This job can be stressful, and I want to be a manager one day.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the cash register and help customers find books. I enjoy helping them, but sometimes it is hard when they want many books at once. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, I meet with book representatives to talk about new books. I make sure new books arrive on time. I finish work at 5:45 pm. Sometimes I work late and close the shop.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then I get up and take a taxi to work by 8:45 am. I talk to reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I help companies understand financial risks. I write reports and send them to my editor. I travel to Africa three times a year for work. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says that many people can be good leaders. To be a leader, you need to find your talents and use them. Everyone can be a leader if they have the right support. It is easy to see great leaders like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be harder to see leadership in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they do it? The best boss motivated you and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss led well; the second boss managed badly.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who writes about leadership, says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad company into a happy one.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you care about and act on it.  
- Think of yourself as a leader. You have the power to lead.  
- Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different ways of leading. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking charge. See how this changes things.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you.

F. Leadership does not just happen. You need to practice leading, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, and give praise.  
- Don’t think everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep working on how you communicate. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be good.  
- Be present and available for important people.  
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when you are needed and how you can help others become leaders too.
