**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is a master at making art from shells. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. 

Peter shows me his work in his apartment. He asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring. He is very interesting and his work is beautiful. He points to some shell decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them. I love them." Peter never planned to sell his art. Five years ago, some friends told him to have an exhibition so more people could see his work. They helped him talk to a gallery owner. 

His first exhibition was in London, and 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices for his art are high, around £2,000 for some pieces. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes his work is special and that people will want it when he stops making it.

Peter wishes he had started making art earlier in his life. He thinks he could have made even more wonderful things. Now, he feels he cannot do as much because he is older. But his work is very different from the common shell art you find in seaside shops. He has a creative mind and makes boxes with tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.

Peter uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His work is very detailed and beautiful.

Peter travels to many places to find shells, like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He looks for shells on the beach. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures. He believes that many shells are broken by people walking on the beach. He thinks it is okay to collect shells that are empty. 

Peter’s work is beautiful, and he loves what he does.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. 

One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist says Kira will be late. Jane worries about this. She thinks models can be difficult and vain. What if Kira does not come? But when Kira arrives, she is smiling and friendly. She is not wearing fancy clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. Kira is tall and pretty. She is with her mother, who is proud of her.

Kira did not plan to be a model. Her older sister told her to enter a model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent in some photos. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. She felt happy and confident. Kira won the competition and got a job with a model agency in London.

Now, Kira has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard, but she says she is still the same person. She is just more confident now.

Being a model is busy. The agency can call her anytime for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends. But her friends understand. They do not complain about her modeling.

Kira has a bright future ahead. She is beautiful and talented. Jane asks Kira what she would do if she were not a model. Kira thinks and says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden are looking for gold. They have traveled from Canada to Africa to find it. Terence is the father, and Chris is the son. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold. They believe there could be 10,000 ounces of gold in the mine. After ten years of digging, they think they are very close to finding a lot of gold worth five million dollars.

Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold. We just need to dig a little more to find it." The father and son have worked hard to find gold. They started their search after Terence read about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. They read old mining books and chose a good place to dig.

They cleared the land, found some gold in the rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to work. They took samples of the earth and removed old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-metre shaft. Now, they need more money. They have spent their savings and need to find someone to give them £50,000 to dig deeper for the gold.

Chris says it is hard to find a backer, but they have some people to contact. Last week, news about their dig spread, and people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the people there are hopeful. Peter Woolven, the manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more tourists here, but I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."

The gold industry in Wales has become smaller since the late 1880s when many people worked in many mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed a month ago. Now, more individual gold-diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He is 70 years old and said, "Searching for gold is very exciting. It is like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She teaches at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. 

When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. Rachel dives three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. 

A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface. Rachel thinks it would not be a nice journey.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency. They tested how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. 

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot.

Once, Rachel was scared when she dived with an American team. They were using equipment when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang, and Rachel thought she would die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. 

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the volcanoes, she feels wonder. She studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

Text: "I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. I was very tired. I could not understand any more train times, money, or languages. 'Never again,' I said when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. I just had to buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five years old, I could travel for a whole month anywhere in Europe. 

Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply. You can waste things, like burning old socks and throwing away finished books. This is part of the fun of Inter-Rail. You can forget about rules and just enjoy your trip. 

With this ticket, young people can travel to many countries in one day. On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra miles did not cost us anything. 

We were not only interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Rail travelers. We made our own plans and only saw the most interesting sights. We wanted to do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. 

We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like many other Inter-Railers who shared the train with us. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only knew by name. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. 

To really understand Europe, you must see it yourself. Everyone knows about it, but it is not the same until you visit. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it takes time."

Text: 'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, you may be in a different place with different weather and have to wear clothes that are not right for that place. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes, and it is hard for any airline to promise that your checked bags will go on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for bags to be checked and put on the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change from one flight to another. This time is often longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights. This can cause bags to be lost. Human mistakes can also happen, like if a bag label gets torn off. 

Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because they handle many bags. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, with many changing planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow. Even good airports like Amsterdam and Singapore can have bad days. 

To avoid losing your bags, try to take direct flights and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to label your bags with your home and holiday addresses, and include your flight numbers. If your bags are still missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report before you leave the airport.'

**Text: The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird. It lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees grow over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and looks like a flash of light. It is gone in a second, but you remember it because it is so special.

Charlie James loved kingfishers when he was young. He does not know exactly why he loves them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. In Greek myth, a kingfisher is a moon goddess that became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom became hot from the sun. 

Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light and look blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or green depending on the light. Many wildlife photographers love to watch them. Kingfishers are shy, but you can watch them from a hiding place. 

Charlie James's first hiding place was an old blanket over his head. He waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in a few minutes and sat very close. But it took him four years to take his first good picture. He spent a lot of time by a stream with kingfishers. School took time away from watching the birds, and he missed lessons. He called himself an "academic failure." 

At 16, he got a job as an advisor for a nature magazine. Then he worked as an assistant to the editor. Later, he became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make a special kingfisher film. He wants no talking, just beautiful images. He likes to take pictures of the kingfisher's wings. 

Charlie thinks about the colors of the bird he loves. His photographs show some of his feelings. But he knows there is much more to his love for kingfishers than what his work can show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.

A. **ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice in Vienna. She ended up helping him because an assistant was not there. Later, she had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. She was not nervous. She likes standing in front of an orchestra. Anne Manson is from America. She works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries. She has helped Abbado on many projects.

B. **ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting good chances to work. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying two other times. He is happy about the timing of his win. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. But he is worried about being known only for the competition. He hopes that in three years, people will know him for his work with orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra.

C. **WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She loves the long practice time for opera. She thinks the music needs four weeks of attention. She began conducting seriously when she was in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was important for her. She liked that Sian was the same size as her. She enjoys the complex nature of opera because there are many different personalities.

D. **ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says conducting surprised him, but he finds it very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. He thought it would be hard, but it was easier than he expected. He knew the music well and tried to get the best performance. He has learned from all his experiences and is open to trying new things.

E. **WAYNE MARSHALL**  
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed him and told his agent about him. Wayne soon had to conduct a musical in London with little notice. It was a tough start. Some musicians were reading newspapers during the show, but he was firm with them. He always gave a clear beat and tried to get the best results. He has not studied conducting formally, but he is determined and knows what he likes.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. We asked five families to try the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, which was very popular. For older kids, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I wanted to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having fun. Our only problem was that the park could be more exciting, and the view was not great. But the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we did not know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We spent six hours there and were happy there were places to rest. The park looked nice, and the staff were friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were glad they were too small for it! The park is so well made that waiting for rides is not boring. It is very clean, and the staff are nice. One staff member helped me with one of the girls when I could not sit with both.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am scared of rides, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then becomes very fun. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I would not go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. The tallest roller-coaster in Europe, the Rocket, is very big. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters high, was worse! There are many main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were nice to younger children, but some were not very friendly. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We could not tell the kids we were going home early.

**Text: Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside.

A. "My customers are friends," says CHRISTINE HOGAN. She has a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted to work from home. I worked with computers before I got married, so my husband suggested I start this business. It was hard at first and I needed a lot of money. I was careful with my spending and told the bank manager if I might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is still a small business. People from the area come to pick up their work."

B. "I enjoy being independent," says MAGGY SASANOW. She designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, and there were no jobs like that. So, I started my own business and make 50 different greeting cards to sell to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working from home is that there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I do not advertise; my business grows by word of mouth. People send me work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. I work alone, so I miss sharing ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad."

C. "It has been hard at times," says DELIA TURNER. She makes curtains. "I started my business eight years ago. At that time, my business grew a lot. In two years, I made £80,000. I had six full-time workers, but I had to let them go because the economy got worse. It was hard because it is not easy to find jobs here. Now, I make the curtains at home with my husband’s help and work with women who work from their homes. I have to lower my prices sometimes and look for new chances."

D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, it was cheaper than London, and second, I love the countryside. I like to work when I want. Most of my money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I take calls at strange times. The bad thing is that I need to be disciplined to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures and work with authors and artists. I felt very alone at first because all my work experience was in London."

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six workers, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I care about health, so I made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building, and now we have a baker and an assistant. I do not bake anymore; I manage the business. My biggest problem has been money because we did not have a lot to start with."

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is very special. They are all musicians. The sons write music and play instruments. Their dad makes the instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins are teachers in South Wales. They have a ten-year-old son named Paul. Paul wanted a cello, but it was too expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He found a school where he could learn to make instruments. He took evening classes for three years. 

After making some violins, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. I used it for many years." John has stopped teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician named Jaime Laredo.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers, "I played the piano first. I loved it!" Later, he wanted to play the cello. His dad played the viola and wanted Paul to play the violin. Paul tried it for six weeks but did not like it. He liked the cellist in his dad's group. That cellist gave Paul lessons, and he started playing the cello.

Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were very supportive. I wanted to be like Paul." Huw is now a pianist and composer.

Paul won a big music competition with the cello his dad made. At 20, he became the main cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his dad's cello until last year. Now, he has a very old cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 

Paul will soon play on television. He will perform Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says, "I will play it my way." But he cannot watch himself on TV because he is playing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw's String Quartet will also perform in London that evening. John and Hetty will be very busy trying to see all their sons' performances!

**Text: Looking after the Countryside**

**THE NATIONAL TRUST**

The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to a warden who works for the Trust.

Gareth Roberts is a National Trust Warden. He says, "You need common sense and you must be good with people." He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders every day. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted to be the warden, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience.

Gareth still helps on his parents' farm. This helps him understand farmers and their problems. He can also do physical work like building fences and planting trees. Since he started working for the Trust, he has learned more about nature. When he was young, he liked to pick flowers and collect butterflies. Now, he sees that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following the government’s rules.

At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted different things. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth says, "We just need a small step to work together."

Gareth's job includes helping people visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. He wants to finish jobs quickly and without problems. He enjoys seeing projects completed, but he also spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, but sometimes he finds it hard to deal with some visitors. He says, "Some people come in, want everything, and then leave. It can be annoying!" But he believes that common sense is important.

If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But remember, there may not be a job available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. 

"Don't you get strange looks?" I asked her. She replied, "I am focused on my movements and my feet. I might see cars slow down, but that is all." 

Kendra said, "My life is about being my best for the Championships." She is following a strict plan to be fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part. "We will have home support, which is special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are at home. People expect us to play well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "We have always beaten them, but they will be fun to play. They are very good," Kendra said. The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. "You must push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games. You can lose the first game in a series and still win. But in the Championships, you have only one chance."

In the fifteen years she has played, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. "You train hard to win," Kendra said. "But after the game, we are all friends."

Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," Kendra said. "As captain, I need to have a strong mind and lead by example. I support and encourage my team."

Kendra said, "My netball career has always been planned. I decided that this competition would be my last as a player." She will coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

What can parents do for a child who is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents may not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special support that regular schools may not provide. 

Children who are musically talented can benefit from going to a specialist music school. There are five of these schools in Britain. They help children aged seven to eighteen develop their music skills with professional musicians. 

At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, and practice singing. They also practice in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. 

These schools are independent, which means they are not run by the government. The classes are small, so teachers can give more attention to each student. Most children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.

However, there are some problems. The cost is high, around £12,000 to £17,000 a year for children who live at the school. The schools try to help with scholarships for families who need money. Also, some parents do not want to send their young children away to live at school. 

The directors of these schools worry about admitting very young children. They want to help children grow up to be well-rounded people. It can be stressful for musically gifted children. Sometimes, their talent may fade as they grow older, and the pressure to succeed can make them feel like they are failing. 

The schools watch how each child is doing and offer help if needed. Many former students say they learned a lot from the music teaching, but some think it is not good to focus too much on music and not enough on other subjects. Many talented music students are also smart and want to learn more in school. 

It might be better to wait until a child is older to decide on a specialist music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects can do well in regular schools with good music programs. Some music colleges offer lessons on Saturday mornings, but this may not be possible for families who live far away from big cities.

**Simplified Text:**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. She has a big garden around her house. This garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wild and spread all over the garden. There are two long flower beds along a path that goes from one side of the garden to the other. The previous owners of the house were good gardeners and left many plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of the flowers Susan wanted to add, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint individual flowers instead of the whole garden. She often picks flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don’t set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it. This can take a few days. Then I bring in another flower and keep painting." Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting.

Spring and early summer are her busiest times when the tulips and poppies bloom. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. She also finds it interesting to see how flowers change over time. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they seem boring, but they become more interesting.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers from the countryside. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers that grew in hard places, like rocks or cliffs.

Now, her garden has many plants from different countries, and they grow well there. She is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they do not break anything. Susan has two art shows coming up, so it is hard for her to work in the garden. She now has another gardener to help her, but she knows that to stay connected to her flowers, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She finished her studies in French and History of Art at university last summer. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. She meets many interesting people every week.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She thinks cleaning is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but sometimes they want to be alone. Good guests can make her week better.

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas and may go to other places later. But on Saturday nights, Sarah does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for guests is at 7 a.m. After breakfast, she cleans quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. At about 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. She gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Then it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she talks with friends, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but here I was busy. Some people on the fashion team looked stressed, but my job is not stressful. At a fashion shoot, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like to see how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo."

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I wore leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. When I touched an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I might work with elephants in Africa."

Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes do not see daylight. It was hard work, but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I did not know gardening was so hard. I like gardening, but I will keep my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on the TV show Ground Force. She worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would feel faint, but I was okay. The nurses are friendly, and it felt nice compared to my usual job with men. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but I felt good about it."

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different. People looked at me. Before the flight, our supervisor told us about safety. I knew some of this from my training. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who would not sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I do not exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I saw that some trainers did not eat very healthily, but they drink a lot of water. I would not change my job for this, but it made me want to join a gym and be healthier."

**Text: On the Rails**

Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys.

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France. I try to go there often. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast to Italy. The views are beautiful, no matter the weather or the time of year. Out of the window, you can see nice gardens and big houses. It feels like looking into the homes of rich people. The people on the train are always happy. There are tourists and locals, all enjoying the amazing trip.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was too young. When I moved to England as a teenager, I saw my first real train station, London Waterloo. The big glass roof amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
One special train for me is the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I still wear it. The journey was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was a perfect way to relax after our wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were writing articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not reliable; we only had a day. The driver sometimes waited for people to arrive. When the train came, many people rushed to get on, even on the roof! At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Many people love trains from when they are children, but I did not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where there were few trains. I started to love trains as a teenager when I made a film in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old train line that volunteers took care of. I loved riding the train, and when I went back last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights on the platform!

**Simplified Text:**

Do you want to get your story published? If you are not sure where to send it, Margaret Stubbs can help you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or a book. Who can I send it to?" 

First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. It is important to know about the market for your writing. You can do this by reading a lot. Go to your local library and visit bookshops. Reading different things will help you understand what publishers want. 

You should keep learning because new magazines and books come out all the time. Publishers always want new writers, so you need to know what they like. 

If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish love stories. Get some recent copies and read them. Learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Readers want different things, and the editor wants to meet their needs. 

Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and say, "This has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I do not want to discourage anyone, but it is hard to get published if your work is not ready. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is very unlikely to be published. 

When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been writing for a long time before that. When you send your work out for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten more stories or even twenty. Each story will be better, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. 

Do not give up on your stories. Try to make them better instead. In the beginning, do not show your work to others. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 

Do everything you can to improve as a writer. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you cannot find one, join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and build your confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**Text:**

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were many more people than I expected. The station did not feel clean and nice like before. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and college students left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around and talking to different people. He looked rich: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft coat. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but to New York. 

Then he asked a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I would like to talk to her too. The man asked her, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said no, and he moved to the next bench. Now I was really watching him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to Wilmington, and he walked away. 

I was going to Philadelphia. I thought he could have asked me, but I understood why he didn’t. He looked at me quickly and then went to another bench. He looked very stressed. He asked a woman reading a book, "Please tell me you are going to Philadelphia!" She looked up and said, "Yes, I am." 

"Can I ask you a favor?" he said. I stood a little away and looked at my wrist, even though I did not have a watch. The woman seemed worried. The man said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man said, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and went home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." 

The woman felt sorry for him. I thought it was better to stay quiet and see what he would say next. The man continued, "I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." 

I thought, "Why doesn’t he go himself?" The woman asked him, "Why don’t you go yourself?" He said, "I can’t leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair." I thought this was not a good excuse. 

I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded envelope. I thought, "Watch out, lady!"

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John found out about a restaurant for sale, he went to see it. The restaurant was in bad shape, but John thought it was perfect for him.

John remembers his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad when she left him alone. He wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money, while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they talked to the customers.

Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a corner bath and hurt himself. As he grew older, he did small jobs for money. By ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend and earned a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.

Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adult cooks and sometimes was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Gary also started playing the drums and has his own band now. John told Gary to focus on one thing at a time. He advised him to achieve his goals by the age of 30. Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished his work very quickly and even helped other students.

Everyone is surprised by how successful Gary's cooking show is. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that to get what you want, you must work hard. Gary has seen his chance and worked for it. John believes that if children listen to even a little of what you say, it is good. He thinks Gary must have listened sometimes.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is to know someone. If you know a person who knows someone else who is moving out, that can help. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you do not know anyone. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. 

Dublin was new and big for Jo. She felt nervous when she took the train to go there. She did not think about why she was going. Everyone at her school thought she would go to Dublin. They wanted to leave their small town and see new places. Some of her friends went to other towns, but Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Jo's father hoped the hostel was warm because many hostels are cold. Jo's sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought it was crazy for her to stay in a hostel for a week. 

Jo saw an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked. Jo hoped it would be nice and not too expensive. There was no line for this flat because it was looking for a third girl to share. 

The flat seemed nice, but Jo was worried it might be too fancy for her. The house was a normal red-brick house, and the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was coming down the stairs. She looked unhappy. 

"Bad place," she said to Jo. "The girls are not nice." 

Jo asked what happened. The girl said, "A girl just looked around and acted like she was better than us. We don’t want her here." 

Jo met another girl named Pauline. Pauline had colorful clothes and hair. Jo thought she looked interesting. 

"I'm Jo, I work in the post office," she said. Nessa, the girl with the college scarf, said they were going to have tea. She got three mugs. One mug had 'Nessa,' one had 'Pauline,' and the other had 'Other' on it. 

"We can put your name on a mug if you come to stay," Nessa said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We go to see them in seaside places, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about this problem.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals. They can feel human emotions, and they make us think of freedom in the ocean. We see this love for dolphins in TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy shows hide the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas.

The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down a lot. It is estimated that there are 89,000 fewer porpoises now. You might think that such popular animals are protected by law and cared for in special places. But this is not true, and this could be a big problem for wildlife.

There are forty different kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We see them in small groups, and we do not know much about them. 

Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often found in places like the Channel coast and the Thames River in Britain. Now, we can only find them in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few dolphins that are left show signs of stress.

It is hard to know exactly why the number of dolphins is going down. Overfishing is taking away a lot of fish from the sea. This is bad for dolphins and porpoises because they need to find food quickly. If fish are taken from one area, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. 

In modern fishing, big nets are often left in the water or pulled quickly through the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also get poisons from the sea. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins can pass these poisons to their babies through their milk. There is already one case of a baby dolphin dying from its mother’s milk.

Another big problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise can disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind and body. It helps you feel good and stay healthy. Many people talk about fitness because it is really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise, and not many reasons not to.

Exercise helps your muscles and changes your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit well. It can stop injuries and helps with areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. Exercise is also good for your heart and lungs.

Exercise can help you feel less sad and tired. It can help you sleep better and reduce stress. It can even help with some health problems. 

There are many types of exercise you can do, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But be careful! If you train too hard, you can get hurt. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are not sure what is good for you.

Good posture is very important. If you stand or sit badly, you may look and feel tired. To help with posture, think of a balloon pulling you up. This can help you breathe better and make your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It helps you move better and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. 

A good exercise routine should include warming up, stretching, a workout, and cooling down.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for a long time? They want to find the perfect shot of animals. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, in a place called the Ngorongoro Crater. It has rained a lot there for six months. This has caused some problems for them. Owen said they had to buy a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud.

Amanda and Owen have made some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their famous film about leopards. While people were watching this film, they were already back in the field, looking for another shy animal, the jackal. Film-makers like them travel all over the world to film wild animals.

I talked to Owen when he was at a safari lodge with other people. He said, "We do have some arguments, but we get over them quickly." They do not see one person as the leader. They both understand animals in the same way. 

When they travel, they set up their tents each night. This time, they are staying in one place. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Owen said, "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a little stressful."

It can be tough, but being in nature helps them get close to the animals. Owen remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go away and then come back to greet her family. She even greeted their car!

Owen first worked with Amanda in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they started working together to film Arctic foxes. They now spend four months in one place to get enough material for each film. Before they start, they must send a script for approval. 

Owen said, "Amanda and I have a good working relationship because we have the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about where she trained. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t see much else."

Kendra said, "My life is about being my best for the Championships." She has a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries playing. "We will have home support, which is special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are at home. People expect us to play well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They are very good." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra said the Championships will be tough. "You must push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games. You can lose the first game in a series and still win. But in the Championships, you have only one chance."

In the fifteen years she has played, netball has become harder and faster. "You train hard to win," Kendra said. "But after the game, we are all friends." Netball is also using more science for fitness. Kendra said, "We must think and train like world-class players." As captain, she wants to have a strong mind and help her team.

Kendra said, "My netball career has always been planned." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. Rachel dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They are used to being in this small space. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is a problem, Rachel can hit a panic button. This button makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space.

Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes. The volcanoes blow out black smoke. The Russian team was leaving scientific equipment to study a project that would make a hole through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves. She teaches so she can do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot.

The only time Rachel was scared was when she dived with an American team. They were using a 50-metre rope when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence. When nothing happened, they were very relieved. They were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the window, she sees the chimneys of the volcanoes. She feels wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen them before. Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume, and our words.

Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to get her degree. When she graduated, she felt very confident. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she did not want to be late. She believes it is important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend who works at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not take time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think what is inside is important, but in an interview, you should try to look your best."

Many people do not think about looking professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant. When her boss retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She asked why and the Director of Personnel said she did not look like an office manager. He told her to improve her clothes before applying again. Janet was shocked. She does a good job, and she thought her clothes should not matter.

How we move and use our hands can also affect what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from our words, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and our face say different things, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how excited she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have gotten more if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you care about the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long sentences. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work in an office in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. "After 14 years in my job, I felt that working in the city was not fun anymore. I wanted to stay for five or ten more years, but then I lost my job suddenly. I did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start my farm. I met the head chef of a local hotel. I started selling meat to them, and now I sell meat by mail order too. I am happy to be out of the office, but I still work a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. "I started painting as a hobby. I enjoyed it more than my job. So, I decided to leave my job and become an artist. A career adviser helped me. I told him, 'I do not want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people want to go back to work for money. My wife and I got married young, and our children are grown up now. We moved to the north of England, where we did not know anyone. We left our friends, but they still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. "Being a lawyer was fun, and I earned a lot of money, but I worked too many hours. I did not want to work more and more, so I left. Some people said I would get bored, but I never did. I have deadlines for my work, so I always have things to do. I feel happier now and less stressed. I miss talking to my colleagues. I love that I am responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, it is my fault."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I worked in finance from the age of 22. I liked the excitement, but I did not find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year. I wanted to find out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited gyms and talked to the owners. I knew I needed training, so I took courses in massage. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control of my life now, and that is the best part."

**Text: 'Four Young Athletes Talk About Their Lives'**

A. **Darius (Runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. Not many people heard about it, which was sad. I hoped to get some money for training, but it is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there, and I have to be very disciplined. If my friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but I need to work hard. My main goal is to go to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

B. **Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are in the morning. If I want to be good, I cannot go to late-night parties. I do not mind this too much, but I love to sleep in. I have to give that up too. But it is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to celebrate, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on TV, so now I am a bit famous.

C. **Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so I enjoy coming back and spending time with my friends. You cannot only focus on sailing; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but not many people recognize me on the street. I do not want to be famous. I get nice letters from fans who want signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.

D. **Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and hear the crowd cheer for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I like being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But it can be hard too. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. I focus on my game now and will think about other things in life when I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything! If it is not the new sugary cereal, it is a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I cannot buy all this. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But I also feel bad when I say no. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I cannot win."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow. Children do not always understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents often talk about how bad sugar is for teeth, but children see fun ads that make them want the products.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. **ICE SKATING**

Ice skating is a fun activity that people have done for many years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around the year 200 AD. For rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. 

In the early 1900s, skating was seen as fancy. But in 1924, a young girl named Sonja Henie changed this. She made skating more exciting and popular. Today, skating is both beautiful and hard work. 

For beginners, it is very important to have balance and control. You can go faster as you get better. To keep your balance, your body should lean slightly forward. Your legs should be a little bent, and your feet should point outwards. When you start, your heels should almost touch. 

To move, push with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It is easy to learn! If you practice, you can make bigger movements as you get better. 

Learning how to fall is also important. Even the best skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps you not to get hurt. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. 

Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, or speed skating. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn freestyle. Many ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn. 

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should practice exercises to stay flexible. It is important to warm up your legs, back, and shoulders before skating. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness. 

Skating helps you with balance, coordination, and movement. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When you skate with swimming or jogging, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Text: 'Trills and Bills'**

F. Jane's mother said, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. I was bored when my father tried to teach me, but Jane loved it. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves and started to beat adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to stop her from being great. If she has this talent, I want her to use it."

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Today, he is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain.

Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are getting taller because we are eating better food now. Professor Chris Stringer says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

Long ago, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and herbs, and men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants. About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Now, most of the world's food comes from just three plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This simple diet has made people less healthy. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Their teeth got worse, and they got more diseases. Corn was not good for health. But farming spread because it could feed many more people than hunting.

Today, many people are still not healthy, even in rich countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, people are starting to eat better again. **Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"

Some people think studio audiences are not important. They say that even TV workers do not respect them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds and jobs. TV shows want to attract different people.

Many people at home do not understand why anyone would want to watch a show in a studio. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and wait in a studio just to see what they can watch at home? One idea is that people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on TV."

Another idea is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But many people said, "A friend gave me a ticket." Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when you see them. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the actors live. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from me, so I watched the show on a monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but that is not what matters. For most people, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Text: HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She said she found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals like this. One night was enough to look at it and read about it in our natural history book.

I got home late. I quickly put a pot on the stove. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. The problem was with Domino the cat and Bianca the white mouse I got for Mother's Day. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room. He wanted to escape with the mouse, but he was running into furniture and kids.

I jumped into the room and tripped over something. I fell on the floor. I saw the snake. It had escaped and was moving all over the floor. The snake was long and strong. The cat, mouse, and kids were jumping around, making a lot of noise. The dog was barking. The pot on the stove boiled over, and I ran to turn it off. I came back with more energy. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the little mouse from him. 

Later, I looked at the snake. It did not have any weak points. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, moving back and forth. Slowly, the snake relaxed and put its head on its body. I carefully put my hands under the snake and stood up. I walked to the end of the garden and pointed the snake to a tree. I was scared it would bite me, but it slid away and rested on my shoulders like a colorful shawl.

We stood together in the evening light: four kids, Mum, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, said, "Mum, you are nice and warm, and the shed is not." I had the kids help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it did. It climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake went away, my three-year-old son Clay said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Text: 'Write Me a Letter!'**

In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming rare. But for me, getting a letter is special. When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote to me, and I loved his funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.

I also got letters from my boyfriends. They were away for work or school, and we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to say what I felt in a letter than in person. I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but letters with news are better! I love getting letters from faraway places, like Sri Lanka, Australia, and Vancouver. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. Now we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her, and we have visited each other.

This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. My children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, too. I hope everyone keeps writing letters and does not let it disappear!

**Text: Climbing Walls**

Climbers used to go to the mountains. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is quiet. High on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is in the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham. The National Indoor Arena is known for the TV show Gladiators, but it also has climbing competitions.

Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When they could not use cliffs, they climbed on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and fight boredom.

Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls. These walls used special bricks to hold on to. A teacher named Don Robinson built a climbing wall in a hallway at Leeds University in the 1960s. He put natural rock in concrete to make climbing walls.

In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built, but they had problems. The walls were straight, but real cliffs have different shapes. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers got bored.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material that looked like real rocks. This material could be put on any wall and taken off when climbers wanted something new. French companies also made climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could make different shapes. This gave climbers many new ways to climb.

**Text: 'So you want to be an actor'**

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is a risky job. Acting can be risky because there are many actors but not many jobs. When you choose to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy. But everyone has different opinions. It is your choice, and you are responsible for your dreams.

There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take tests, but there is no guarantee you will get a job after training. Success depends on luck and talent. There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.

Many people want to know what talent is. Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person’s courage and belief in what they do. 

Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform.

If you ask actors how they succeed, they may not know. They understand some things about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they must keep working hard because their fame may not last. 

Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been without a job, selling clothes or waiting tables. Then, you may get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job, you might not get it. 

Actors often do not talk about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and rejection. No one likes to be rejected. From the first moment you try to get a job, you are saying you are ready and talented. If you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.
