Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they talked to me in English, so we could understand each other.

Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called her late at night because I felt lonely.

The ballet classes in Russia are harder than in England. I eat a lot to have energy. This helps me do well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends.

Now that I feel at home, I like to walk around the city and visit different shops. In December, it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time of year! My room is warm and cozy.

Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

The Arctic is a special place. In summer, many people visit to see the midnight sun. In winter, there are not many people, and the snow and ice are quiet. In the late 1980s, people thought winter could be fun. 

In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a snow building called an igloo in Jukkasjarvi. This igloo was on the frozen Torne River. Many visitors came to see it. One night, some guests decided to sleep in the igloo. They liked it very much, and the idea of an ice hotel started.

Now, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world. When winter starts, a team of builders, architects, and artists come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They work on it until January 7th. The hotel is made of snow and ice, and it is built outside. Sometimes, the weather can change the plans.

In spring, when it gets warm, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, it is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, even if it is very cold outside. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves when they stay at the hotel. It is also good to bring sweaters, scarves, and thick socks. Guests should wear bigger shoes for thick socks.

If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order them when you book your stay. The clothes will be in your room when you arrive.

The ICEHOTEL is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It is 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people came to the shop. There were special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). 

The shop's normal hours are 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours. However, it had to close after only half an hour. 

A police officer said, "We knew a lot of people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers decided to close the doors. The people outside were angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait in line. 

There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.

One customer, Jenny Smith, said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. It was not safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I do not want to wait in line again."

**Text: Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is now a very active group for arts. 

**Society Magazines**  
We make good magazines, like the popular Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by famous British writers and gives new writers a chance to print their work. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can see articles from recent issues on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We have the National Short Story Competition, the biggest competition for short stories. Anyone aged 18 and over can enter. Stories can be about any topic and should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay to enter, but non-members pay £5. The competition is open from April to October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has worked with schools to help children and teachers with writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998. It is for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is a nice place for members. It has vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm on weekdays and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members all over the world. Anyone aged 18 and over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter is a free-diver. She has four world records in free-diving. In free-diving, people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep while holding her breath. She swam back up without help. A year before, she went deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man’s world record in any sport.

A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya believes safety and training are very important. Most free-divers focus on one or two events, but Tanya trains the same way for all her events. She spends two-thirds of her training in the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she does not want to hurt her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit.

When Tanya practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She tries to do fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important for her to not get tired because that can ruin her training.

When she is not training, Tanya makes public appearances to promote sports products. She also helps environmental groups by doing research or making films. Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring the sea life in rock pools. She says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. Because she is famous in some countries, people listen to her when she talks about the environment.

Tanya is now in her thirties. She plans to keep breaking her own world records. She started free-diving when she was twenty-five, and she does not want to stop for many years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons exciting for everyone. In the late 1970s, many people thought cartoons were only for children. But then, some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and children can enjoy cartoons together. However, not all cartoon films were good. For example, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role. 

"I never thought I would spend my first year at university making a TV show called The Finnegans. I only acted in school, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I always wanted to play her. 

I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She said they wanted to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the part. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director and asked him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

Filming started a week after university began, so I asked the university for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to write my missed essays. I didn’t tell my friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel so lucky. 

After university, I want to be an actor. I am not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I have not received any offers yet. I don’t know how I did it all because I also had a busy social life. When filming finished, I didn’t know what to do. I have acted in two college plays since then. 

Unfortunately, I have not been home much. Now that my first year at university is over, I am going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, I wanted to earn enough money to feed my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' is a big company that is growing all over the world. I have learned a lot since we started. I want to share what I have learned in this book. I believe we can run a successful business and still keep our values. 

This is not a normal business book, and it is not just about my life. The main idea is that to be successful in business, you need to be different. Business can be fun, and it can be done with love. It can also help people. In business and in life, I want to enjoy myself, feel like a family, and be excited by new things. I want the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. 

This book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and to what we can do. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

**A Journey on the Douro River**

Jules Verne runs a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can hold 160 guests in double cabins. All cabins have outside views and a private shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning. On the ship, you can find a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the evening and fly to Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will sleep for the night.

**Day 2:** In the morning, you will see sights in Oporto. After that, you will return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the trip takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will keep traveling up the river. In the evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where they make port wine. At dinner, you can try the tasty food and drink from this area.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will go by bus to the old town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. If the river is deep enough, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach and see many things along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. You will return to the ship for lunch and then take the Douro river valley train for a nice ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before going back to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel a long way, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. 

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey and used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help with tiredness and improve sports performance. Honey is not just food; it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. It has been a place to live for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. In 1066, when the Normans came, it was one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a place for many religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and celebrated its 900th birthday recently. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years of being a city. This meant it could govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It grew for 300 years and became rich. It was famous for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a busy place for business, especially for insurance services.

Norwich has many fun things to do, like theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. There is also a football team with green and yellow colors. The team is called 'The Canaries', but no one knows why.

One new place in the city is a shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, there was a big hole in the city because builders were working on it. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and trees. The people of Norwich are happy that the old market is still there, next to the new shopping centre. Both places are busy, showing that Norwich has a good mix of old and new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky in Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, is full of bright colours. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, which happens every year for nine days. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a car park in Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries are expected to come.

**What to See**

The pilots talk to each other on radios. They light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great time to take photos. You should arrive just after night falls or before 5:30 am to see the "glows" as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are in many sizes and colours, some look like animals or cartoon characters, and some are shaped like popular drinks and fast food. Kids will love it!

In the afternoon, you can fly in a balloon over the desert with one of the many companies that offer rides. You can also take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere, and you can see the festival from above.

There are many other fun things to do for visitors of all ages, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a special wind pattern that helps balloon pilots. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This helps skilled pilots control where their balloons go.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets early (you can buy them online) to avoid a long wait. Wear several layers of thin clothes. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and don’t forget your camera. If you use film, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

**Text: The Eden Project**

The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists. The big 'biospheres' look like something from a science fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. It shows how important plants are for people. Many things we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. There are over 135,000 types of plants here. Even if it is cold outside, heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. There is also a zone that looks like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. They plan to build a desert zone soon.

**Text: No Title**

Some people have said they do not like this year's book, New Writing 3. I do not understand why. This book has 500 pages of good writing for £6.99. That is great! Most of the book has stories. There are short stories and parts of novels. Some famous writers, like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain, have written in this book. 

It is interesting that many less-known writers wrote about food. I suggest you do not read Jane Harris's story, Those Nails, after eating. It has some very bad scenes that might make you feel sick! 

There are also poems from nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can read parts of novels by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. There is a little non-fiction too. One funny article is by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers. Ursula Owen wrote a special piece about herself. 

This is a great collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will be!

**Text: Learning the Violin**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violin teacher. "It's a good time to learn about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to teach children who are three or four years old. She sometimes teaches five-year-olds who really want to learn.

Margaret started teaching the violin in 1972. Her first class had her children’s five-year-old friends. Her students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson is one hour long, every two weeks. Each student also has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons.

In the first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not read music for several years. At first, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret says her method is not to make great violinists. She tells students who do very well to leave and learn with other methods.

**Text: Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. The CD is called "Here Again." It comes after their last CD, "The Waves." There are some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott plays the bass guitar now. He replaces Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer.

The first song on the CD is a dance song. This shows that the band will not focus on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance song and is very loud. Most of the other songs are slow, like the band usually plays. These two dance songs will surprise many fans. They could become popular because they are very good.

The singer, Rob Letchford, sings very well. He reaches every note perfectly. Fans are happy he recorded the songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. Fans who bought tickets do not need to worry. The concerts will be rescheduled when Rob feels better.

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles. They have slow songs and dance songs that make you want to move. I think they put their best songs at the beginning, and the last songs are not as good. Still, "Here Again" will be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to see this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it in 1769. San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbour, but it was found by land, not by sea.

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to find gold. But the people who got rich were not the gold miners. The rich people owned banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill.

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco. They want to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote a famous diary in English. It talks about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events, like sickness, a navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself. He sometimes slept in church and looked at pretty girls. He tells about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and he worries about her being sick. Pepys liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He had many important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

**The History of Shoes**

A long time ago, shoes were not very comfortable or stylish. People used animal skins to cover their feet. They tied these skins around their ankles when it was cold. Today, we still use leather for shoes, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton. 

About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started to wear different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were the same shape and could be worn on either foot. 

In the past, all shoes were made by hand. Now, many shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped make many shoes quickly and at a lower price for more people.

**Text: No Title**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women enjoy running. I wanted to show them how fun it is and help them feel good about running. I started a running club for women in my area because I was unhappy with some race organizers. They say there are not enough women in running, but they do not make good places for women to change.

I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. Many of them wanted to lose weight, but I think they did not think about running before. When they did think about it, they thought it was hard and painful. They did not think about having fun, talking, and smiling while running in nice places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes! They also learned about healthy food and staying fit. I wanted to help women with running, and I feel very happy to see how much they have improved. They are happy too!

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people came to Alaska to find gold and get rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means "far, distant place." In 1909, Iditarod became the largest city in Alaska for a short time.

In summer, boats brought supplies to the towns. But in winter, rivers and the ocean froze, and boats could not come. So, in 1910, a winter path was made for dog teams pulling sleds. They took mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took a team of dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at "roadhouses" to sleep and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams. But in 1925, there was a big problem. A disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and no one knew if they could fly in the cold. The best pilot was away, so they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine.

The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to finish the journey. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian looking for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo. Togo was a good guide in the snow. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, stopped the team from falling into icy water. The medicine arrived, and Balto became a hero.

Now, every year, there is a dog sled race from Anchorage to Nome. This race follows the famous route from 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

**Text: Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Sweden. In winter, it can be very cold, up to -40 degrees Celsius. Many people visit this place every year. They come to see a special hotel made of ice. 

In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even have a wedding there. The bar is made of ice too, so you should not put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4 degrees Celsius. Guests get special sleeping bags to keep warm. They can also get warm clothes if they need them.

The hotel is new every winter because it melts in summer. Each winter, workers build it again. It takes a lot of ice and snow to make the hotel.

**Text: Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on a boys' football team in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one cared that I was a girl. But then the other team complained." A local newspaper wrote about her story. Jose Craveirinha, who helped African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside. He saw that she was very fast.

Jose talked to Maria about athletics. She did not understand at first because she only knew about football. Then he bought her running shoes and took her to train. It was hard work, and her legs hurt. Jose spoke to her parents and told them she could be successful. They agreed to let him help her train.

In 1991, Maria went to train in the United States. She had said no before because she would miss her family. The girls in the US were good athletes, but they worried about different things, like dresses and make-up. Maria worried about her parents having enough food. She felt lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and she learned a lot.

Today, Maria still runs and lives happily in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon is in the United States. It was made by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and see the view. The view is very beautiful, especially from the Skywalk. 

The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass. You can see the pretty rocks of the canyon through the glass. Up to 120 people can stand on the Skywalk at the same time. It opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. 

You must wear special covers on your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains are in North America. They start in the North-west and go down to the south. The Rockies are smaller than the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your trip in Vancouver. Vancouver is a nice city in Canada. You can ski in the mountains just 15 minutes by car from the city. 

Before, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to go across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still very exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you see the beautiful views at night.

**Text: ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. A long time ago, the rulers of China made a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In early zoos, animals did tricks for visitors. Now, this does not happen. Today, zoos are places where people can see animals acting naturally.

Most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people think zoos are good. They say zoos help us learn about nature and see wild animals up close. 

Other people do not like zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and do not get good food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from other high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, and other bands wore bright T-shirts. We did not look like professional adult bands, but we played very well. Everyone was young, but we were used to performing. Players from each band even made new songs on stage. It was exciting to watch, and it was even better when my band played!  

My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the people who want to play can be in the band. But anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps in the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not hard enough for people like me who care about music. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can make your own music, but you also feel part of its history when you play on stage like great jazz musicians before you. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and parents who help us. Without them, we would not get far with our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain from November to March. It does not rain often, but when it does, the streets can flood with water. The people of Marrakesh are happy when it rains because many winters are dry. 

Marrakesh has parks and gardens, but they do not get water from rain. They get water from underground channels. These channels were made a long time ago, in the 11th century. They bring water from the mountains all year round. 

Places that are mostly dry and get water this way are called oases. 

If you go south from Marrakesh, you will find Skoura. In Skoura, people use all the land they can to grow food. There are water channels that make small squares of land for farming. The Atlas mountains, which have snow in winter, look beautiful in the background.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has two older brothers. They work in banking and computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown. 

Three years ago, Gareth and his parents joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it is true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath looked for jobs in the circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started to train to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. 

They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers can take care of the house while they are away. Kath says, "It was not easy. We had to think about many things. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in. We left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long baths."

Gareth says, "People ask about my education. But wherever we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my friends at school, and I have a computer. I have not fallen behind." 

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a hard choice, but it is the best way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I am happy, and we enjoy it." And Gareth? He says, "I will be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. The members are aged 8 to 18 years old. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three places in the country where young people can meet and join projects. We want to open more places soon. Since we started in 1994, over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: "I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was surprised by the chances they had. Age was not important; they could do stories by themselves. I started going to the Eight-eighteen place in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me do more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19, and now I check articles for a big news website."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and join monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen helps members share skills. "Peer trainers" are members who are 12 years old and older. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. Some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. Older staff support these young trainers on their trips.

Eight-eighteen News has training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is good for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

During the short summer in Antarctica, we take tourists on a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. The flight dates for next year are not ready yet, but if you book now, you can change your date if needed.

**Questions**

Here are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**  
The flight is about 12 hours. After about four hours, we see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica talk about the environment and history, and they answer questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers get two boarding passes. At the middle of the flight, you will move to the seat on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and a seat at the end of the row for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane to see the sights.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans. The captain checks the weather on the morning of the flight and chooses the best direction for clear views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives far below the plane, so we cannot see them well. We do not land in Antarctica because of environmental reasons. To see wildlife, you would need to go on a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities where you can wear Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen learns to cook on Saturdays. Many children want to join, so there is a waiting list of 30 kids. Parents pay £280 for the course. The children have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill is ten years old. He says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh when we eat the food we made."

Flora is twelve. She has trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby for the weekends. I was happy at home, so I did not want to come at first. But now I am very glad I came."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It is great fun. Children pay attention and remember better than adults, but the kitchen is not always clean when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, the children will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous for driving. It is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be on the road when you go over a hill. Ice can be under the snow, making the road slippery. A car coming towards you can slide on the road.

**Rule Number One**: Drive smoothly. If you move the car too quickly, it can be hard to control. When you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or go faster, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you do not spill it.

**Rule Number Two**: Pay attention to what might happen. If there is a lot of ice, look further down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. You may be driving faster than you think. 

In general, when the road is wet, allow double the time to stop. On snow, allow three times the time, and on ice, allow even more time. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. In art school, he found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He became interested in early Italian artists, and this can be seen in some of his paintings. 

Aitchison loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colors thinly, one on top of another, from light to dark. He said, "It's a secret - because I don't know what will happen." He does not start with a color like yellow and plan what to put on top.

Aitchison thinks painting is easy. He said, "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors are next to each other." He does not make drawings before he paints because he thinks he might get bored. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes to paint people who do not want to see their pictures while he is painting. He said, "If they are worried and want to look, I can't paint."

Since he moved to London, Aitchison has not felt part of the Scottish art scene. He does not want to follow any tradition; he just paints in his own way. Still, his work influences young British painters.

**Text: Rock Band**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we did not want to buy it because of the noise. Ben said, "It is better than watching TV or playing computer games. It will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play."

This was just the start. Drums are big and hard to move, so Ben's friends came to our house with their guitars and other music equipment. Now, for many hours each week, our house is loud with their music and singing. 

When the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must say, even if their music is a little strange, they are a nice and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good musicians, but they play at local clubs for young people.

Our main worry is that they will not do enough school work because of music, but this has not happened yet. I always tell Ben that his studies are very important. But one thing is clear: Ben was right. Playing music has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College. It is a good private college in Wales. The college helps young people learn about life outside the classroom and study for their exams. 

The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from many countries. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities. They might help on a farm, care for people with learning difficulties, or check rivers for pollution. 

Atlantic College has students from different backgrounds and countries. Many students cannot pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants to help them. About a quarter of the students are British, and many get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I admire the college for helping young people understand each other. You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don’t like them. My mother said I argued less with my sister during the summer."

In summary, Atlantic College gives its students a great education with methods that work well.

**Text: Being an Older Student**

I am 32 years old. I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes and learn to read books quickly. I also write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. 

Before, I worked as a secretary. I earned good money, but I was bored. I did not have to think much at my job. I felt sad because I thought I was stuck in that job. I saw students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to feel that way too.

Now that I am a student, I find it hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers. Even though we are the same age, I know less than they do. 

I am happy to study because I know I need a good qualification to get a good job. This is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer to spend my weekends reading books instead of going to parties. 

I also enjoy the benefits of being a student, like long holidays and discounts for the theatre and cinema. Sometimes I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that going back to school now is a good choice.

**Text: Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen years old, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong and light steel to make cars that were cheap for regular people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant there were fewer choices. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 

'Dear Sir, 

I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I want to know more. How much is a course? How long is each course? When does the next course start? 

Yours, 
Maria Gonzalez 

Dear Ms. Gonzalez, 

Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course is 6 weeks long and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that is 10 weeks long for £200. 

I hope this helps. 

Yours, 
David May'

**Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS'**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she was a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and her family and traveled to Asia with some other climbers. She found that life on Everest is hard. 

"You must carry everything on your back," she said. "You can only take what you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and I didn't even take a toothbrush. I am usually clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job on a science program on television. Rebecca is well known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon said you were sick and stayed in bed. Are you better now? It was a great party! Many of my friends were there and they gave me nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

**Text: CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are big blue and white birds. In autumn, they fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. 

Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know what to do in autumn." Bill had a small plane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. 

All summer, he flew short trips in his plane, and the young geese followed him. When autumn came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. 

Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They did not come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks but could not find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther left school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon made £1,000.

At first, her parents did not want her to make jam. They wanted her to study and hoped she would be a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen. She kept making jam. After a few months, she sold it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice and sold it to a school where her friend worked.

After two years, her business grew a lot, and her parents were happy. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was very busy and needed to hire some people to help her.

Text: 

'Dear Jacqueline, 

Do you want to go to the cinema with me after school today? We can see Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? 

Love, Isabella 

Dear Isabella, 

I am sorry, but I can't go to the cinema today. My mother has work, and I will cook dinner. You can invite Karen to go with you. I hope you like the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. 

Love, Jacqueline'

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. Most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep. Each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they do not get too warm.

Five years ago, Jenny made sweaters with the wool. She tried to sell them at country markets, but it was summer and hot. People did not want to buy sweaters. So, she made socks instead. Everyone loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business started.

At first, Jenny made the socks at home. Soon, she had many customers. She had to send the wool to a factory. Now, all the socks are made by machines. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. 

Jenny is very busy at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

Text: 

'28 Long Road  
Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,  

I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many countries, and I have made new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like my teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me when I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.  

Best wishes,  
Maria'

**Text: 'BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told us that house burglaries have gone up by more than 30% compared to last year. He said that 67% of burglaries happen when people go out and forget to close a door or a window. 

He also said that night-time burglaries are not common because families are usually at home then. But winter afternoons are good for burglars because it is dark and they cannot be seen easily. Many houses are empty at that time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch other houses when people are not home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 

"We will also tell you how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This help costs nothing."

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, 

Thank you for the two nights I stayed in your nice home. It was good to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are nice photos, right? I hope you like them. I love my new camera. I will visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I have not seen my sister for a long time. Thank you again. 

Love, Roy'

Text: 'The History of Farming

Before farming, people looked for plants and fruit in the forest to eat. They moved a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people started to grow food. These people were the first farmers. Farming helped people stay in one place, and their villages became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers grew food for everyone. But farming was hard when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels a long way to our homes.'

**Text: WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet left school when she was eighteen. She went to college and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she worked for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Later, she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she became a manager.

This is what she said about her job: "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

At work, the first thing I do is check plane times on my computer. Then, I talk with some air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. 

Travelling can be hard. When I come back from a long trip, I just eat something and then go to bed! I do not earn much money, but I am happy with British Airways. I want to stay there and keep traveling."

Text: 'Dear Maria, I am happy to be back home, but I still think about my friends in our English class, especially you. I was sad when I left England because my visit was short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study harder. How are you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 

'Dear Sir, 

I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10. It is a big blue bag, and my name is on it. Did you find my bag? 

Yours, 
Mary Johnson 

Dear Ms. Johnson, 

I am happy to tell you that we have your bag. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6:30 p.m. every day. 

Yours, 
J. Wilson'

Text: 'The Weather People care about the weather for many reasons. The weather is important for many jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to learn about the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather. People can also get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people think that if cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two boys who are 14 years old. They live in a small town in Canada. They are good friends and go to the same school. Like their friends, they like to go fishing or swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they have stayed in Peter's room every weekend. They are not doing a lot of homework. They made a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin. Kevin has trouble with reading. He learns words better with pictures and sounds than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make the game. Now it is ready to use. It is a game with speaking and pictures. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there is a picture of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter say 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be sold around the world. Many schools want to buy it.'

Text: 'HOW DOES THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? 

Sleeping well is very important. When I go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my head is full of music. 

Sport is also important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now, I cannot do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups every day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I drink a lot of water because it is good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I do not always drink that much. 

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also like to do other things. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. I do not feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

**Text: Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, so it is the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians like to watch films more than anything else in their free time, and ten million people go to the cinema every day. 

Bollywood films often tell love stories, and singing and dancing are important in every film. People outside India also enjoy Indian films. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs more than $5 million to make.

Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is one of India's greatest actors. He has been the star of more than 140 films in his almost 40-year acting career.

Text: 'Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States. I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. Now, we live in the United States. Our children are learning about life here. I think they will be happy because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon. So, I will not go back for four years.

I just went to England for six weeks. I worked on a radio show about the English language and talked about my new book. Most writers do not like to travel and sell their books. I do not mind it. I like to visit new places and meet people. It is very different from my life in the United States when I write. In England, people drove me in big cars and I stayed in nice hotels. It was good because I did not have to pay for anything. Everyone was nice to me and it was fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago. The Giant Schnauzer is bigger and has not been in England for a long time. The Giant Schnauzer is 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, and they need haircuts often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany. Farmers use these dogs to help with sheep. The police also use Schnauzers because they are very smart. Schnauzers are good family dogs. They are friendly and great with young children.

**The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help make a road through a forest between two big towns.

Mary said, "It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food." It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. The Ruwenzori Mountains are one of the wettest places in the world.

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

Text: 

'Dear Keira, 

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me the classrooms. She is very nice. I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths. I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time. I really liked it. Most of the teachers are friendly, but I am scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. 

I must go now because I have to do my homework. 

Hester'

**New Books This Month**

**The Long Night**  
This is David Reilly's first book. David was a teacher before he became a writer. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick. Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to a big city. They have many problems on the way.

**Hard Work**  
This is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat. He works with his father, who is a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have money. One day, a man in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

**Hospital or Cinema?**  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story this year. Tina is a young woman from Brazil. She wants to be a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. One day, a man asks her to go to the USA to become a film star. What will Tina do?

Text: 'The History of Horse Racing

Horse racing is an important sport. It started a long time ago, about 4,500 years ago, in Central Asia. People in ancient Greece and Rome liked horse racing too. 

Modern horse racing began in Europe in the 12th century when Arab horses came to Europe. At first, there were long races with only two horses. But in the 18th century, races became shorter and had many horses running together. 

Today, many people watch horse racing in the USA. It is the second most popular sport after baseball. Horse racing is also popular in other parts of the world.'

Text: 'Nick Barlow is a world traveller. He is a British actor. He travels to many countries to make TV shows. "People are nice to me everywhere," he says. "When I go home, I remember all the good things that happened." Nick has been to many places, but he wants to visit South America and go back to Australia one day. 

Nick travels with a team. They bring cameras and other things to make the show. Nick does not take many things for himself. He takes a few shirts and trousers, but he always has some books in his suitcase. 

Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him travelling. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick comes home, she likes to hear his travel stories. 

Sometimes, there are problems. When Nick was in the Malaysian rain forest, he heard that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt bad because I could not help her, but she did not want me to come home. I was very happy when I heard she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

Parrots are beautiful birds. They have lovely colors and long tails. You can see them in forests or zoos. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in big groups. Parrots like to eat fruit, so they can be a problem for farmers.

There are many kinds of parrots. All parrots have strong beaks and feet. They use their beaks and feet to climb and hold food. Some parrots can live for 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart. You can teach them to talk. Some zoos have shows with parrots. You can see the parrots do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER

Bray is a beautiful village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young man named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know his name yet, but he is already famous in France. He has written in French magazines about many good restaurants in France. He is 29 years old. 

When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He liked this so much that he decided to spend his money on visiting France and eating in good restaurants instead of buying clothes and CDs. He also bought many cookbooks. He says he has more than two hundred and fifty cookbooks!

Why did he open a restaurant? He loves cooking. Is it easy to do? He says it is expensive to start a restaurant and it is harder to cook for fifty people than for his family, but he believes he has made the right choice.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small park in England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers. Last week, he was in Tokyo. Many people in Japan watched him on television because he is a famous singer there. John went to Japan a few months ago to sing in clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on his show. Many young people called the DJ to ask for more songs. 

John sings under the name Jon Otis in Japan. He will still work in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from singing. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, "This will not change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

**To:** All staff  
**Subject:** Holidays

I am planning the holidays for next year. Please tell me when you want to take your holiday. If you can, please give me two dates. Please answer by the end of the month. Thank you.
