**Memo**  
**To:** D Brown  
**Subject:** Holidays  
**From:** J Green  
**Date:** 23.2.02  

Can I take two weeks of holiday in July? I want the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are OK. Also, can I take three extra days in the first week of December?  
John

**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have a new hobby: line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It is a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are young and old people. The boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet when they dance!"

When did line dancing start? Most people think it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world. The Black and White Rhinos live in Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. Rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is hard and they have little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They walk slowly, but they can run fast, up to 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm. They eat grass and plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays in its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live for 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

A long time ago, in 1700, there were no policemen in London. Only a few old men walked the streets at night to help keep people safe. They did not get paid much money. 

As London grew bigger, it became very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money, so people stayed at home to be safe. 

In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding paid some people to stop the thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. 

Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was still very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force started with 3,000 officers. Most of the men walked, but some rode horses. 

Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police get paid well, and the few police officers who ride horses get paid even more.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Do you want to go on a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus. We will stay at a camp-site from Friday to Sunday. There are hot showers and a small shop. You can rent bicycles. The trip costs £25. It is very cold at night, so take warm clothes and strong shoes. If you want to come, tell me today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, for the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from many countries. They come to Edinburgh for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from morning until night. You can see artists painting pictures on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students do funny shows in small places like cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to see new films and plays and hear music from famous musicians. This year, you can see over five hundred shows with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are not very expensive, and it is usually easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will find Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake is covered with ice, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. 

Bob Marvisch has come here for twenty-five years. He says, "You need light but warm clothes: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

First, you break the ice and make a small hole. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer chocolate or another snack! Today I caught twenty-five! It is a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!

Text: 

'From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I am not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was better than us. Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called me with bad news. He cannot come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We cannot go camping together now. This morning, my sister got up late and rode my bike to school. She did not tell me she needed it. I am really angry with her.  

I hope you have good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg'

**Text: Madame Tussaud's**

Madame Tussaud's is a famous place for tourists in London. In this museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor who made wax figures. He opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with this work. 

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie went to prison. In prison, she had to make wax heads of famous people who were dead, like Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she came to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum, and her figures can still be seen today.

**BICYCLES**

A bicycle is a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive. Only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from today’s bicycles. Later, bicycles became cheaper, and many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and for fun. 

Today, many people use cars more than bicycles. Cars are faster, and you don’t get wet when it rains! But some people still like to ride bicycles to work. They say there are too many cars in town, and it is hard to find a place to park!

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand with my family. We had a beach holiday. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flowers, but we wanted to see the elephant show. 

We went to a big area with seats. Three elephants came in with their trainers. They stood in front of a large white card. Each elephant had a paintbrush. They started to paint on the card. The trainers gave them new brushes with paint and took the old ones away. The elephants painted pictures. I was amazed! One picture was of a river, one was of a tree, and the third was of flowers. When the trainers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one.

We also gave the elephants bananas that we brought for lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore. The smartest elephants live in special places where people can watch them.'

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many kinds of cats. They are different in size and look. Tigers are the biggest cats. They can be 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Most cats do not like water, but tigers like to lie in water when it is hot. 

Lions are the only cats that live in big family groups. Many lions work together to find food for the group. They usually live in flat, open places where they can see far and follow other animals easily. All cats need good eyes to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I am sorry, but I cannot come to your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will make a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sad to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you. Best wishes, Soraya.'

Text: 

'14 Sheffield Road  
Rotherham  
20th May 2002  

Dear Mary,  

I will be in London next Thursday morning. Do you want to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where to meet you. I hope to see you then.  

Yours,  
Joan  

20 Didsbury Drive  
London  
22 May 2002  

Dear Joan,  

Thank you for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. Can we meet outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant near there. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don’t be late!  

Yours,  
Mary'

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I am happy because last month I got a new job. I work in a Tourist Information Office in the city. It is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I get up early! I love this job because I meet people from different countries. I like to tell them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH

The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, up to 90 kilometres an hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow up. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.'

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson is a snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now she is 23 and has won many competitions. We talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland last week. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I have always liked sports, especially skiing. It was easy to start snowboarding. You can learn quickly and get good in a few months." 

We asked her if she practices a lot. She said, "In winter, I snowboard every day in the mountains from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains. It is very beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best for me." 

We asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn fast, but you need lessons. It is also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet because you will fall down a lot at first!"'

Text: 

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,  

I want a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15 to 17. I would like a single room with a shower. I also need a telephone in my room. Please give me a quiet room on the ground floor. I will drive to the hotel. Is there a car park? I will arrive at about 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close? If possible, I would like a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your help.  

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro. They can be very young, like a seven-year-old boy, or very old, like an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and many tourists use this path. 

Only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro reach the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and it can be very cold, below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring sunglasses and warm clothes!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. Otters live near rivers. They make their homes from small pieces of wood. Otters usually come out at night. They are very good swimmers and can swim fast. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose. This helps them stay under water for a long time. 

Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were dirty, and many fish and insects died. Otters could not find food. But today, there is a lot of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

Text: 'Dear Deshini, 

I am happy that you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write to me about your life in India. I want to know if you live in a small village or a big town. What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school? I am sending you some photos of my family. I will send more next time. I hope you write to me soon. 

Tom'

Text: 

'17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,  

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a good teacher. I liked my time in Cambridge. Now I am at my brother's flat. He is studying to be a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go home to Greece. I like London a lot. We went to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was sunny and we had fun. Tonight, I will see a film with my brother and his friends. I will write again from Greece.  

Best wishes,  
Kostas'

Text: 

'Dear David, 

I will visit your country next month. I will travel with two friends. We do not know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We want to stay in the center. Can you help us? 

Carlos 

Dear Carlos, 

Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria. She says you can stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay for you? 

David'

**Text: Buildings**

People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We have other buildings, like museums, to keep beautiful things.

Many people work together on a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures of their ideas. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers build it carefully.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous building with a beautiful roof. It looks nice from every side, not just the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich is also famous. It looks like a tent made of glass.

Text: "Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. I don't have anything to wear. I have grown a lot, and all my trousers are too short! I want to buy new trousers and maybe some boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Do you want to meet me in the morning or afternoon? Let me know. Sarika"

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one hill, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. 

Nobody knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on the first of May when the sun comes up, you will see many people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is a great runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run in the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail often came second in big races. She always smiled, and people in her city love her for this.

In 2004, everything changed when she ran her first half-marathon, which is a long race. She won and had the fastest time of the year for any British woman runner. 

Gail's husband, Mike Rollins, was also a runner when he was younger. He had to stop racing because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him.

Gail trains hard. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. She always rests from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should eat that?' It is usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything."

**Text: Piano Players - When They Were Young**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from the opera. His mother started to teach him the piano when he was six. When he was ten, he wanted to write music and began his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who liked to play the piano, taught him some Russian music. At six, he started lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg soon won prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Then, he returned to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two. A year later, he started to play the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he gave fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef liked music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is busy now, but one day he wants to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist. He became a writer of children's books when he was 60 years old. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she does not like something," says Bill. 

Bill has ten grandchildren. They do not live near him, but they read his stories and tell him if they are good or bad. This helps Bill know what young children want to read. 

Bill writes about life in his village and on the farms nearby. His favorite book is his fifth book, called *The Sheepdog*. It is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill. "Dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." 

Last year, they made a film of the book with real animals and actors. The film-makers used new technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes film-makers change books, but they did not change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, people like to send postcards to friends and family. Postcards often have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are cheap. The pictures on postcards are often better than their own photos.

The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed news events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these postcards because newspapers did not have pictures then.

**Text: Dinosaurs**

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago. This was a long time before people were on Earth. Nobody knows why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. 

Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds of dinosaurs. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest dinosaurs were larger than any other animals that lived on land. 

For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long, and it ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat. It could also run fast because it had long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can hurt a person. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run fast. But they cannot see well. They find food by using their noses.

There are seven types of bears. The biggest is the white polar bear, which is almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown.

Many people love the black and white panda bear from China. Not many pandas live in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles live in warm places in the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They like to stay in slow water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You can often see many crocodiles together. They eat fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they can eat big animals or even people. There are more than ten kinds of crocodiles. They have very sharp teeth. They can lose their teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some are bigger. They can live a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon to take people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers made the first plane with an engine. They flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 

Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world. It can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 

Today, many people travel by aeroplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof. People got cold and wet if it rained. The queen liked to go to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to see plays by William Shakespeare. All the actors were men. Visitors ate food, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! 

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place by the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life in the 1600s.
